you're the internet's busiest music
nerdy and it's time for a review of this
new Billy Woods project church this is a
new one from one of the most elusive
voices in hip-hop today Mr Billy Woods
treating us to his second project in
2022 which is a bold move considering
how good the one he dropped in April was
ethiops there was an impressive roster
of features on this thing from boldie
James to LP to despot which proved just
how much his cult profile has grown over
the years in many ways this record was
also a flex of this man's increased
knack for lyrical imagery and heady
references some of his most
forward-thinking production choices
landed on this thing too and I also saw
this record as not only an Embrace of a
lot of the modern day abstract hip-hop
Aesthetics that are popular right now
but an improvement on them if Billy
Woods has proven anything over the years
it's that he is a fine tuner his
progression over the past decade has
come very clearly but gradually from
album to album and I think I've heard
him on this streak long enough to know
when he is stagnating a bit on a project
because in my opinion church does not
feel like another step forward or even
an extension on the strides he made
earlier this year because in many ways
this record reminds me of a project
Billy had a hand in uh years back that
would be Rome the 2017 album from The
Duo he makes up with a lucid Armand
Hammer I suppose This Record feeling
like a previous release from Arm and
Hammer shouldn't be too surprising
considering that the Arsenal of
production on this thing is raised by a
messiah music who is a frequent Arm and
Hammer collaborator the very simple bear
Moody and textured loops on Church's
beats uh very much hearken back to that
project especially in how repetitive
they grow after a while but I think the
parallels extend beyond even that the
song structures on this thing aren't
super present either there's little
little to no variation across many of
these tracks that is until we may hit a
random Fade Out that suddenly introduces
an entirely different beat which will
often introduce such a radical and
disconnected shift in sound and vibe
that it might as well be an entirely
different song I'm thinking of the last
leg of parquot for example and sometimes
the random detours these tracks head
into go harder than everything that came
before that moment in the song like in
the final leg of classical music where
we get this mystical Lo-Fi ballad that I
wish there was more of there's also
fever grass who's very woozy and
intoxicating instrumental in the first
half is not bad woods tops this with a
memoir style description of a younger
self kind of surviving day to day in a
very dysfunctional surrounding but where
the track really gets started is again
after a beat switch and he begins to
dive into his family tree starting with
his grandfather and then from there
rapid firing all these very overwhelming
memories which again hit so painfully
hard and I wish this section of the
track went longer and deeper into what
it's describing and and even that the
song started earlier on this progression
then there's also fat Rays verse in the
uh second half of schism which arrives
with a beat switch that again I think is
uh superior to the instrumental before
it you have these insane read samples
that uh have this intense chorus on them
they really pop and raise delivery is
marked with this kind of raspy beastial
tone that reminds me of like Sean price
at his prime so yeah there's these
tracks that are undergoing these uh
somewhat random and sometimes
unnecessary changes but even the tracks
that aren't engaged in this are lacking
in their own way like the very brief
swamp water which I found to be too
fleeting there's the song Frankie as
well which so much of this track is sunk
into the intro that by the time it gets
started it doesn't really have the
chance to build up too much momentum the
song artichoke I found to be way too
one-dimensional too little contrast
across the refrains and verses and this
pitter-patter groove combined with these
kind of very uh pitchy and fluttering
lead Melodies that get stale after a
while yet it really does kind of like
start to itch at me I think topically
and geographically Cossack wedding
brings an interesting switch up with all
these creative tie-ins between Soviet
era Russia imagery and a toxic
relationship that Woods still seems to
have expectations for but the lumbering
grooves on this beat in the very sparse
flows that are brought to the table on
this one makes it feel like we're
hearing a rough cut of a demo that's not
quite fully sculpted yet really I think
a lot of the tracks on this thing had
potential but they didn't quite make it
one of the few examples of a song truly
coming through on this thing is the song
uh Pollo Rico serious diamond in the
rough on this record not only are the
somber Oregon cords and the chunky beats
on this cut mesmerizing but the lyrical
focus on this track gives it such a
devastating sense of mortality and
finality that just blows nearly
everything else here out of the water
plus you also have Woods trademark wit
mixed with this very deep deep deep
pessimism on some of the best bars one
where he makes reference to soldiers who
were only given half of what they were
promised after a revolution they were
engaged in another where he says his
uncle told him that you can't bury all
those bodies you have to burn them in a
pile it was dark I could see his teeth
it wasn't a smile given a track like
this I think this record could have
found a lot more power in the Simplicity
it was obviously trying to employ I
think that also occurs on the track
fuchsia and green the thick psychedelic
production on this cut and the vocal
delays are a delight sonically plus you
have that usual Arm and Hammer chemistry
going on between elucid and woods that
is definitely a pick-me-up in the first
half of this LP the other track
featuring Lucid on The Closer was also
very easily a highlight on this thing
which makes me also think that maybe
this record should have just been like
you know formulated into another Arm and
Hammer album because for the vast
majority of this thing I feel like the
material is just too dry it's too loose
it's too underdeveloped in that sense it
kind of reminds me of the elusive record
that dropped earlier this year too
because to make an analogy here I feel
like we're getting a lot of peanut
butter
but not enough jelly and you know it's
